stem: A 68-year-old client is 4 days post-large anteroseptal myocardial infarction (MI). Based on the provided documentation, which finding is most indicative of a ventricular septal rupture (VSR)?

options.text: New holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (LLSB) with a palpable thrill.
New murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla.

rationale.correct: A **ventricular septal rupture (VSR) (a1)**, a lethal mechanical complication, typically occurs 3-5 days post-MI as necrotic tissue softens. The hallmark findings are a **new holosystolic murmur** at the **left lower sternal border (LLSB)** with a **thrill**, and echocardiographic confirmation of a **left-to-right shunt**. This causes sudden right-heart overload and cardiogenic shock. Mitral regurgitation (a2) from papillary muscle rupture would have a similar murmur but would be heard at the *apex* and radiate to the axilla. Hypotension and muffled heart sounds (a3) are indicative of cardiac tamponade. A pericardial friction rub (a4) is associated with pericarditis.
clinicalPearls: VSR = Hole in the septum. Murmur = LLSB.
Papillary Rupture = Mitral Regurgitation. Murmur = Apex/Axilla.
Both are surgical emergencies and cause rapid shock.
Treatment involves an Intra-Aortic Balloon Pump (IABP) to reduce afterload and emergent surgery.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing hypotension because the client is in shock.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While hypotension is present, it is a result of the underlying complication. Focus on the specific assessment findings that differentiate the potential complications. A loud murmur after an MI always suggests a structural defect (Septal rupture or valve dysfunction).

exhibits.title: New Clinical Assessment
exhibits.content:
Situation: Sudden onset of dyspnea and hypotension.
Cardiac: New, loud holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border (LLSB). A palpable vibration (thrill) is felt in the same area.
Lungs: Bilateral crackles throughout all lobes.

exhibits.title: Stat Bedside Echo
exhibits.content: Impression: New defect in the interventricular septum with large left-to-right shunt. Normal valve function (no mitral regurgitation). Pulmonary artery pressures are significantly elevated.
